awd_titl_txt: CREST-PRF: Exploring the dynamics of strongly coupled spin-photon systems
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Centers of Research Excellence in Science and Technology (CREST) Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (PRF), this project aims at exploring strong light-matter interactions on well-known color centers in diamond by interfacing engineered diamond membranes with photonic cavities. These interactions bring further tunability to the overall optoelectronic properties of color centers, forming a hybridized half-light half-matter system with potential applications in the areas of neural networks and enhanced nanoscale sensing. The current efforts within the community have been directed towards strong coupling of individual color centers in solids, which is challenging in fundamental ways. Instead, this project aims at reaching strong light-matter coupling with dense color center ensembles to explore collective phenomena and emergent properties of these hybrid states. Such collective behavior is expected to enhance nanoscale sensing and provide a platform for next generation computation. 

The specific aims of the project are oriented towards reaching the so-called ‘strong-coupling regime’ with nitrogen-vacancy and silicon-divacancy color centers in diamond. In this regime, the light/matter components are not independent anymore, and collectively describe what would be a defect-excitation-cavity-photon hybrid state. In realizing such goal, it is important to assess the physical requirements for the diamond samples such as thickness and defect densities, as well as optimal photonic-cavity designs. To elucidate these details a priori, analytical, and numerical methods will be used to ‘inverse-design’ the hybrid diamond-cavity systems. Such designs could be based on light-matter coupling strengths that can be reliably measured in experiments, by Fourier-space imaging, and time-resolved spectroscopy methods. These approaches will help understand the photophysical dynamics of strongly coupled color centers, as well as assessing their potential tunability and integration via photonic interactions. The CREST PRF awards provide research experience and training for early career scientists at active CREST Centers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Exploiting light as a nanoscale intermediary between matter components for quantum and nanoscale applications relies on our understanding of the intricate interactions between photonic and material degrees of freedom. It also relies on our ability to manipulate and interface photonic and material systems at the nanoscale. This CREST-PRF project contributed to these broad areas of materials science and engineering through a few different fronts:

(i)     Design, fabrication, manipulation and integration of highly-optically-active diamond membranes with nanoscale photonic cavities. Part of this work allowed for a cost-effective, reproducible and efficient design for diamond hybrid photonic microcavities. 

(ii)     Combining probe microscopy with enhanced confocal fluorescence and magnetic resonance instrumentation in a state-of-the-art microscopy setup for the characterization of light-matter interactions at the nanoscale. Parts of the instrumentation efforts of this work were put in designing and constructing a home-built microscopy system with capabilities for non-local excitation/collection confocal fluorescence microscopy and time-resolved spectroscopy, interfaced with an atomic-force microscope. The system can be operated remotely and can be integrated with angle-resolved spectrometers for state-of-the-art non-local photonic experiments.

(iii)     Combining highly-optically-active diamond nanoparticles with topological photonic devices as potential spin-photon interfaces. A direct application of this home-built system allowed to study the excited-state dynamics of emitter-dense diamond nanoparticles in contact with a topologically non-trivial photonic element, designed to host directional photon propagation based on the polarization of light. The non-local collection capabilities of the aforementioned microscope allowed for the experimental observations of the strong photonic effects on the large emitter ensemble, characterized by strong polarization tunability and directional propagation of fluorescence from the diamond nanoparticle. This constitutes an observation never reported for this material system under ambient conditions.

(iv)     Extending the theoretical description of the underlying mechanisms through which a large ensemble of optically detuned emitters interacts with a polarizing photonic element to become optically polarized in a tunable fashion. The physical phenomenon of pure dephasing describes how photonic interactions can become predominant despite the loss rate in the light-trapping device is much larger than what is needed to reach the so-called strong-coupling regime – at which light and matter cannot be regarded as separate. In work devoted as part of this project, we have combined and extended previous theoretical models to capture how polarization – in this case a material degree of freedom particularly interesting in connecting photons and spins – plays a role in the pure dephasing mechanism and can be used as an asset to control the degree of polarization and light propagation/out-coupling from the solid-state emitter.

In terms of scientific products and publications, the main activities of this project yielded two scientific publications (one under review) and supported ten related articles (three published, one accepted, and five in preparation). Some of the main results were shared through two scientific talks and two poster presentations at international conferences, including the APS March Meeting and the Gordon Research Conference.

Lastly, as a postdoctoral research fellowship, this project also allowed the Recipient to fostered skill development, collaborative network expansion, and experience in research budgeting and reporting.
